Chapter 4, Section 5: The Distinctions of Karmic Retribution. Thus far, the characteristics of the ten karmic paths have been explained.
Based on what meaning is it called karmic path?
Verse:
Among them, the last three are only paths, because they are the paths of karma.
The corresponding volition is called karma, because it turns due to them, it proceeds due to them, and it is created according to their power.
The first seven are karma, because they are bodily and verbal karma, and they are also the paths of karma, because volition moves due to them.
Because the volition that gives rise to bodily and verbal karma turns based on bodily and verbal karma as its object.
Karma and the path of karma are established as the karmic path, therefore, in this context, the term karmic path fully reveals the meaning of the karmic path, karma, and the path of karma.
Although they are not of the same class, one is the remainder of the other, because this is well established in the scriptures.
The seven, such as abandoning killing, and the three, such as non-greed, are established as the names of karmic paths, and this should be explained in the same way.
Why are the preparatory and subsequent actions not karmic paths?
Because they only occur based on this.
Also, it was previously said that they are included because they are coarse.
Also, they are established as karmic paths because by these, there is decrease and increase, and internal and external things have increase and decrease, but it is not so for other [actions].
The DÄrá¹£á¹­Äntikas hold that greed, anger, etc. are themselves mental actions. Based on what meaning do they establish the name karmic path?
One should ask them.
However, it can also be said:
Because they are mental actions and evil destinies, they are established as karmic paths. Or, because they mutually ride, they are all called karmic paths.
The ten evil karmic paths as explained above all contradict the arising of good dharmas.
By what karmic path are the roots of good severed?
What are the distinctions in the characteristics of severing and continuing good [roots]?
Verse:
Only wrong views can sever the roots of good. Those severed are the innate in the desire realm.
All severing is gradual. Two are abandoned together.
Humans in the three continents, both male and female, sever by views and practice. Non-obtainment is severed.
Continuing good, doubting, and having views suddenly manifest, excluding those who commit heinous crimes.
Treatise:
Among the evil karmic paths, only the highest and most complete wrong views can sever the roots of good.
If so, why does the original treatise say, What are the highest unwholesome roots? They are the unwholesome roots that can sever the roots of good?
Or, in the stage of separation from desire, they are the first to be eliminated. Because the unwholesome roots can lead to wrong views, the matter of wrong views is attributed to those roots.
Just as fire burns a village, the fire is started by thieves. Therefore, the world says that the thieves burn the village.
What roots of good are severed by this?
It refers only to the innate roots of good in the desire realm. The good of the form and formless realms are not established first.
How can you reconcile this with the Abhidharma-vibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra,
which says:

â€œIt is only by this amount that a person has cut off the wholesome roots of the three realms. It is said that the wholesome roots above are more distant, because this continuity is not their container.â€
Why does one cut off only the wholesome roots acquired by birth?
Because the wholesome roots of added effort have already been lost.
What kind of wrong views can cut off the wholesome roots?
It is wrong views that definitely deny causes and effects.
Those who deny causes definitely deny good and evil conduct.
Those who deny effects definitely deny the retribution of those effects.
Other masters say that
these two kinds of wrong views are like the paths of immediate succession and liberation.
Other masters say that
the wrong views that cut off the wholesome roots have only impure objects and not pure ones, and they have only the realms as objects and not other realms.
This is because they only create bonds and latent tendencies, and objects do not increase according to circumstances, because their power is weak.
Those who explain it in this way say that it is common to all objects, and that it is also a cause of increase, because it has powerful force.
Other masters say:
The nine grades of wholesome roots are suddenly severed by a single moment of wrong view, just as the delusions eliminated by the path of seeing are eliminated.

Those who explain it in this way say that the wholesome roots are gradually severed, that is, the nine grades of wholesome roots are gradually severed by the nine grades of wrong views, with the reverse and forward sequences corresponding.

Just as the delusions eliminated by cultivation are eliminated in the path of cultivation, the upper-upper wholesome roots are severed by the lower-lower wrong view, and so on up to the lower-lower wholesome roots being severed by the upper-upper wrong view.
If this is the explanation, it accords with the treatise.
As the treatise says:
What are the wholesome roots that accompany the subtle?
It is said that at the time of severing the wholesome roots, they are the last to be abandoned. Because of abandoning them, one is said to have severed the wholesome roots.
If that is so, what principle does that passage again explain?
What are the upper grades of unwholesome roots?
It is said that the unwholesome roots that are able to sever the wholesome roots.
This statement is made in a sense of ultimate completion, because at that time the roots of goodness are completely severed.
If there is still one category of good roots, the remaining categories of good roots can arise from it, and it cannot be said that the good roots are severed.
When the severance is complete, it is called severing the good roots. Therefore, only the superior category is called that which can sever the good roots.
Other masters say:
Severing the nine categories of good roots is never like the path of insight.
Those who say this allow for both the possibility of severing and not severing.
Other masters say:
One first abandons the precepts and then severs the good roots, because it is not easy to abandon them.

Those who say this claim that if the precepts are the result of the mind of this category, when the mind of this category is severed, one abandons the precepts, because the result is of the same category as the cause.
In what place can one sever the good roots?
In the three continents of the human realm, not in the evil destinies, nor in the heavens.
Why is this?
because in the evil destinies, defiled and undefiled discernment is not firm, and because in the heavens, one directly perceives the results of good and evil actions.
The three continents refer to the three continents excluding the northern continent of Uttarakuru, because there is no extreme evil intention there.
Other masters say:
Only in JambudvÄ«pa.
If that is so, then it contradicts what is said in the Abhidharma.
As the Abhidharma says:
The people of JambudvÄ«pa have a minimum of eight faculties, and the same is so for the people of the eastern and western continents.
In what kind of body does one sever the wholesome roots?
Only in the bodies of men and women, because their intentions are firm.
Other masters say:
Also not in the body of a woman, because desire, effort, discernment, etc. are all dull.
If that is so, then it contradicts what is said in the Abhidharma.
As the Abhidharma says:
If one possesses the female faculty, one definitely possesses eight faculties. The same is so for the male faculty.
In what kind of practitioner can the wholesome roots be severed?

Only those who practice views can sever the roots of goodness, not those who practice love, because the evil intentions of those who practice love are extremely agitated, while the evil intentions of those who practice views are extremely firm and deep.
For this reason, eunuchs and others cannot sever the roots of goodness, because they are of the type who practice love.
And because this type of person is like those in evil destinies.
What is the substance of this severence of the roots of goodness?

You should know that the severence of goodness takes nonacquisition as its substance, because when the roots of goodness are severed, the acquisition of goodness does not arise, and nonacquisition continues to arise. The state in which the nonacquisition of the roots of goodness arises is called the severence of the roots of goodness.
Therefore, the severence of the roots of goodness takes nonacquisition as its substance.
By what means are the severed roots of goodness restored?
They are restored by doubt and the view of existence.
That is, one sometimes gives rise to doubt regarding cause and effect,
thinking, This may or may not exist.
Or one gives rise to right views, definitely thinking, It exists, not non-existent.
At that time, the acquisition of the roots of goodness is restored, and because the acquisition of goodness arises, it is called the restoration of the roots of goodness.
Other masters say:
They are gradually restored in nine stages.
Those who hold this opinion say that one suddenly restores the roots of good and then gradually manifests them later, just as one suddenly cures an illness but gradually regains strength.
Can one restore the roots of good in the present body?
There are those who can restore them, with the exception of those who have committed the five heinous crimes.
The scriptures say that such a person
cannot restore the roots of good in the present life.
This person can restore the roots of good either when he is about to die in hell or when he is about to be reborn there, but not in other states.
The phrase â€œwhen about to be rebornâ€ means in the intermediate state.
The phrase â€œwhen about to dieâ€ means when he is about to die.

If he has cut off the roots of good through the power of causes, he restores them when he is about to die. If he has cut off the roots of good through the power of conditions, he restores them when he is about to be reborn. You should understand that the same is true of the power of oneself and the power of others.
Moreover, those who have destroyed their good roots through the destruction of intention but not through the destruction of practice can restore their good roots in the present life.
If the intention is corrupted and the practice is also corrupted, and one severs the wholesome roots, one must continue the wholesome roots after the body is destroyed.
If the view is corrupted but the precepts are not corrupted, and the view is corrupted and the precepts are also corrupted, and one severs the wholesome roots, one should know it is also like this.
There are those who sever the wholesome roots but do not fall into wrong views. Four alternatives should be made.
The first alternative is the one who is called PÅ«rá¹‡a.
The second alternative is the one who is called AjÄtaÅ›atru.
The third alternative is the one who is called Devadatta.
The fourth alternative is the one who excludes the above characteristics.
Having already explained the severance of the wholesome roots by taking advantage of the opportunity, one should now further clarify the meaning of the fundamental karmic paths.
Among the wholesome and unwholesome karmic paths that have been discussed, how many arise simultaneously and how many thoughts do they accompany?
Verse:
The karmic paths that accompany thought, unwholesome, from one to eight,
The wholesome, generally up to ten, specifically prohibited, one, eight, or five.
Treatise:
As for the number of thoughtconcomitants that occur together with volition in the various karmic paths, in the case of unwholesome actions, volition occurs together with from one to eight.

One occurs together with one, i.e., when one of the three, craving, etc., occurs apart from the others, or when one of the unwholesome thoughts is present at the moment of the completion of an action of bodily or vocal karma that was initiated previously by a nondefiled thought.

Two occur together with two, i.e., when one kills with an angry mind, or when one is covetous at the moment of taking what is not given, or when one engages in sexual activity, or when one utters frivolous speech.
Three occur together with three, i.e., when one kills and steals at the same time with an angry mind.

If this is so, then the explanation that the karmic path of stealing is completed by covetousness would be invalidated, but this is not so, because it is completed by the covetousness that is not different from the thought that actually carries out the act of stealing. You should understand that this is the explanation. If one initiates the action of an unwholesome bodily or vocal karma with a covetous mind, then two are completed at the moment of the completion of the action.
Four occur together with four, i.e., when one utters false speech or coarse language with the intention of destroying another, then one has one mental action and three vocal actions.
If one first prepares to commit an evil bodily action, then the three of craving, etc., are present at the moment of completion.
The same is true of five, six, and seven.

Eight are present when one first prepares to commit the other six evil bodily actions and then personally commits sexual misconduct at the same time as the completion of the other six. The last three karmic paths are never present simultaneously, and therefore there are no nine or ten.
We have now explained the number of times the evil karmic paths are present simultaneously with volition.
In general, the good karmic paths may be present simultaneously with volition up to ten in number.
But according to their characteristics, one, eight, and five are excluded.
Two are present simultaneously, i.e., the five good consciousnesses and the knowledge of extinction and nonproduction in the formless realm, when the seven good mental activities are absent.
Three are present simultaneously, i.e., when the mind associated with right views is present, the seven good activities of form are absent.
Four are present simultaneously, i.e., when a mind of evil or indeterminate is present, one acquires the precepts of the devotee, the novice, or the full monk.
When six arise simultaneously, it means that when the five consciousnesses are present, one obtains the three precepts.

When seven arise simultaneously, it means that when good volition is present, accompanied by the three precepts, or when a defiled or indeterminate mind is present, one obtains the precepts of a bhiká¹£u.

When nine arise simultaneously, it means that when the five consciousnesses are present, one obtains the precepts of a bhiká¹£u, or when the cognition of exhaustion and non-arising is present in the formless realm, one obtains the precepts of a bhiká¹£u, or when volition associated with the cognition of exhaustion and non-arising included in the meditative absorptions is present.

When ten arise simultaneously, it means that when good volition is present, accompanied by the three precepts, or when any other mind accompanied by the three precepts is present, along with any form that is not included in the precepts.
This is a specific and obvious explanation of what is prohibited. If we discuss what is hidden and obvious, then there is nothing prohibited.
It means that apart from the precepts, there are one, eight, and five.
As for one arising together, it means when an evil or indeterminate mind is present, one obtains one branch of the precepts.
As for five arising together, it means when wholesome mental consciousness without concomitant form and associated with right view is present, one obtains two branches and so forth.
As for eight arising together, it means when this mental consciousness is present, one obtains five branches and so forth.
In which realms, destinies, and places are the wholesome and unwholesome courses of action?
How many are only accomplished and how many are also actually present?
Verse:
Unwholesome in the hells, coarse, mixed, and anger are both,
Greed and wrong views are accomplished, in the northern continent the last three are accomplished,
Mixed speech is both accomplished and present, in other desires the ten are both.
Wholesome in all places, the last three are both accomplished and present,
In the formless and non-percipient heavens, the first seven are only accomplished,
In other places they are both accomplished and present, except in the hells and the northern continent.ğŸ”½Treatise:
Herein,
In the three evil destinies, the three evil destinies are of two kinds.
As for the ten evil courses of action, in the hells the three of coarse language, frivolous speech, and anger are both manifest and stored.

That is, because they revile each other, there is coarse language; because they wail, there is frivolous speech; because their bodies and minds are coarse and strong, unruly, and undisciplined, and because they hate each other, there is anger.
Greed and false views are stored but not manifest, because there is no attractive object and because they directly see the results of action.

Because death is due to the exhaustion of action, there is no course of killing. Because there is no appropriation of property or women, there is no course of taking what is not given or sexual misconduct. Because there is no need for it, there is no lying. Because of this and because they are always absent, there is no divisive speech.

In Uttarakuru, greed, anger, and false views are definitely stored but not manifest, because there is no appropriation of property, because body and mind are soft and yielding, because there is no harmfulness, and because there is no evil thought.
Only defiled speech is both actual and perfumable, because sometimes one sings with a defiled mind, but without an evil intention.
They do not have killing, etc., because their life span is fixed, because they do not possess property or women, because their body and mind are soft, and because there is no need for them.
How do they engage in sexual misconduct?

When men and women arouse desire for each other, they hold hands and go to the foot of a tree. If the branches of the tree hang down to cover them, they know it is appropriate to engage in sexual activity. If the tree does not hang down its branches, they feel ashamed and part.
Except for the above hells and Uttarakuru, the other realms of desire have all ten that are both actual and perfumable.
That is, in the heavens, hungry ghosts, animals, and humans of the three continents, the ten evil karmic paths are both actual and perfumable. However, there are differences.

That is, the heavens, hungry ghosts, and animals only have the seven karmic paths of the middle that are perfumable, not those of undisciplined conduct. In the three continents of humans, both kinds exist.
Although the gods do not kill gods, they sometimes kill beings of other destinies.
Other masters say:
Gods also kill gods, but their lives are ended only when their heads are cut off or their waists severed.
The unwholesome have been discussed.
Among the wholesome courses of action, the three beginning with noncovetousness are both possessed and performed in the three realms and five destinies.
The seven beginning with nonkilling are possessed but not necessarily performed in the formless realm and among the unconscious celestials.

That is, holy beings born in the formless realm possess past and future uncontaminated moral precepts. Unconscious celestials necessarily possess past and future moral precepts of the fourth trance state.
However, holy beings, according to the stage of their bodies, have at one time produced and lost uncontaminated moral precepts.
When they are born in the formless realm, they possess the past of that stage. If they possess the future, they possess the uncontaminated moral precepts of the five stages.
The remaining realms, destinies, and places, excluding the hells and the northern continent, all seven good paths are common to both actual dharmas and perfections. However, there are differences.

That is to say, ghosts and animals have the unwholesome paths of action apart from the precepts, but if in the form realm there are only the precepts. The three continents and the desire heavens all have both kinds.
What are the fruits obtained by unwholesome and wholesome paths of action?
Verse:
All can attract the fruits of retribution, equal flow, and predominance,
Because they cause others to suffer, cut off life, and destroy dignity.
Discussion:
First, the ten evil paths of action each attract three fruits.
What are the three?
Because of the distinctions of retribution, equal flow, and predominance.
That is to say, if one practices, cultivates, and does much of the ten kinds, by the power of this one is born in the hells, which is the fruit of retribution.

Having left that realm, they are reborn in the human realm and experience the results that accord with the cause, namely, that those who kill have a short lifespan, those who steal lack sufficient wealth, those who engage in sexual misconduct have unfaithful spouses, those who speak falsely are often slandered, those who engage in divisive speech have discord with close friends, those who speak harshly always hear unpleasant sounds, and those who engage in idle chatter are not respected.
Those who are greedy have excessive greed, those who are hateful have increased hatred, and those who have wrong views have increased delusion, because delusion increases in that category.
This is called the specific result that accords with the path of karma.
Short lifespan among humans is also the result of good karma. How can it be said to be the result that accords with killing?

It is not said that the human lifespan is the result of the karma of killing, but rather that because of killing people, their lifespan is shortened. It should be understood that the karma of killing acts as an obstructive cause for the life faculty of humans, causing it to not remain for long.

The dominant fruits obtained from these ten are as follows: Because of killing, the external things that are enjoyed are of little luster and vitality. Because of taking what is not given, they are often struck by frost and hail. Because of sexual misconduct, they are full of dust and dirt. Because of false speech, they are full of foul odors. Because of divisive speech, the place one lives in is dangerous and treacherous. Because of harsh speech, the fields are full of thorns and brambles, barren and salty, and crops do not grow well. Because of frivolous speech, the seasons change.
Because of greed, the fruits are few. Because of hatred, the fruits are spicy. Because of wrong views, the fruits are few or none.
This is called the distinction in dominant fruits of the paths of action.
Does a single act of killing cause the retribution of rebirth in the hells and also cause the shared quality of a short lifespan in the realm of humans?
Or is there anything else?
Other masters say:
A single act of killing first causes the retribution of rebirth in the hells and later causes this shared quality.
Other masters say:
The two fruits have separate causes, the first being the preparatory action and the second being the fundamental action.
Although the text says in general that one killing constitutes one kind of retribution, in fact it includes the root and its branches.

The text says that the result of similar evolution is not beyond the result of retribution and the dominant result. It is provisionally called similar evolution because it is similar to the result of retribution.
What is the reason that each of the ten kinds of action is said to have three results?

First, in the state of killing another, one causes another to suffer, one cuts off life, and one loses dignity. That is, when one kills, one causes another to suffer. Therefore, one falls into hell and suffers the result of retribution. Because one cuts off the life of another, one is reborn in the realm of humans and suffers a short life as the result of similar evolution. Because one destroys the dignity of another, one causes external things to be few and lacking in luster as the dominant result.
The other evil actions should be considered in the same way.

Consequently, you should understand that the three results of good actions are the opposite of the above. That is, if one abstains from killing, if one cultivates and practices it much, and if one does much that is good, by the power of this, one is reborn in the heavens and experiences the result of retribution.
Having died there, they are reborn in the human realm and experience the results that accord with their actions, namely, those who abstain from killing have a long life.
The rest should be explained according to the opposite of this.
Also, a scripture says:
Among the eight wrong paths, wrong speech, wrong action, and wrong livelihood are distinguished as bodily actions.
Apart from wrong speech and wrong action, what is wrong livelihood?
Although there is no wrong livelihood apart from them, it is separately explained. A verse says:
Bodily and verbal actions born of craving are wrong livelihood, because they are difficult to eliminate.
Because grasping livelihood arises from craving, it is unreasonable to contradict the scriptures.
The treatise says:
Bodily and verbal actions born of hatred and delusion are called wrong speech and wrong action, respectively.
Bodily and verbal actions born of craving are established as wrong livelihood separately because they are difficult to eliminate.
Because craving can steal the minds of sentient beings, the actions produced by it are difficult to restrain and protect.
In order to cultivate the correct livelihood with utmost sincerity, the Buddha separately explained it apart from the previous two.
As a verse says:
It is difficult to eliminate wrong views in the world, because one always holds different views.
It is difficult to protect wrong livelihood in the path, because one's requisites belong to others.
Other masters hold the view:
Only the two karmas of body and speech born from craving for the requisites of life are called wrong livelihood, not the others born from craving.
Why is this?
Because one performs singing and dancing, etc. for one's own amusement and pleasure, not for sustaining life.
This contradicts the sÅ«tras, so it is definitely not correct.

In the SÅ«tra on the Aggregate of Precepts, the World-Honored One also established watching elephant fights, etc. in the midst of wrong livelihood, because one falsely prolongs one's life by observing external objects in a wrong way.
Right speech, right action, and right livelihood should be understood in the opposite way.
As previously stated, there are five kinds of fruits. Which karmas have how many fruits?
The verse states:
Karmas with outflows on the path of cutting off have five fruits in full.
Karmas without outflows have four, namely, excluding the matured fruit;
The remaining karmas with outflows, good and evil, also have four, excluding the fruit of separation.
The remaining pure and indeterminate dharmas have three fruits, excluding the above-mentioned fruits.
The treatise says:
The path that can realize and eliminate, and that can eliminate afflictions, is called the path of elimination, which is the uninterrupted path.
This path is of two kinds: contaminated and uncontaminated.
Contaminated paths have all five fruits of karma.
The retribution fruit is the attractive retribution attracted by the path of elimination in one's own stage.
The outflow fruit is the subsequent similar dharmas of equal or increased power in one's own stage.
The disjunction fruit is the unconditioned liberation realized by the power of this path in eliminating afflictions.
The human effort fruit is the co-existent liberation and cultivation attracted by the path.
The dominant fruit is the conditioned dharmas other than one's own nature.
Excluding only those arisen previously.ğŸ”½The uncontaminated path in the path of elimination only has four fruits, excluding the retribution fruit.
The remaining contaminated wholesome and unwholesome karma also have four fruits, excluding the disjunction fruit.
Because they are different from the previously discussed path of elimination, they are said to be the remaining.
The remaining words in the following should be explained in the same way.
That is, remaining pure and indeterminate karma only has three fruits.
Excluding the previously excluded fruits of retribution and disconnection.

Having already generally distinguished the karma that has fruits, next we discuss the characteristics of karma with fruits in different aspects. Among them, we first discuss the three types of karma such as good.
The verse says:
Good and so forth with regard to good and so forth, the first has four, two, and three,
The middle has two, three, and four, the last has two, three, and three fruits.
The treatise says:
The last mentioned all correspond to the previous meaning, as appropriate.
That is, taking good, bad, and indeterminate karma as causes one by one, according to their order, we discuss the number of fruits with regard to good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas.
The following should be understood by analogy.
That is, the first good karma takes good dharmas as four fruits, excluding retribution.
It has two fruits for unwholesome [karma]: the human fruit and the dominant fruit.
It has three fruits for indeterminate [karma]: excluding the homogeneous fruit and the disjunction fruit.
Middling unwholesome karma has two fruits for wholesome dharmas: the human fruit and the dominant fruit.
It has three fruits for unwholesome [karma]: excluding the karmic maturation fruit and the disjunction fruit.
It has four fruits for indeterminate [karma]: excluding the disjunction fruit.
What is the homogeneous fruit?

It refers to the pervasive unwholesome [karma] and the remaining unwholesome karma abandoned by seeing suffering, which take the indeterminate dharmas of the category of the view of self and extreme views as their homogeneous fruits.
Later indeterminate karma has two fruits for wholesome dharmas: the human fruit and the dominant fruit.
It has three fruits for unwholesome [karma]: excluding the karmic maturation fruit and the disjunction fruit.
What is the homogeneous fruit?
It refers to the indeterminate karma of the category of the view of self and extreme views, which takes the unwholesome [karma] as its homogeneous fruit.
It has three fruits for indeterminate [karma]: excluding the karmic maturation fruit and the disjunction fruit.
Having discussed the three natures, we will now discuss the three times.
Verse:
The past has four fruits in the three times, the present and future are also so.
The present has two fruits in the present, the future has three fruits in the future.
The treatise says:

The three kinds of past, present, and future karma each take past, etc. as their fruits, as appropriate. This means that past karma takes dharmas of the three times as its four fruits, excluding only disconnection.
Present karma takes the future as its four fruits, as explained above;
it takes the present as its two fruits, namely the human effort and dominant fruits.
Future karma takes the future as its three fruits, excluding the similar and disconnection fruits.
It is not said that later karma has earlier fruits, because dharmas that precede it are definitely not the fruits of later karma.
Having discussed the three times,
we will now discuss the various stages.
Verse:
The same stage has four fruits, different stages have two or three.
The treatise says:
In the various stages, whatever stage the karma belongs to, it takes the dharmas of the same stage as its four fruits, excluding disjunction.
If it is contaminated, it takes the dharmas of different stages as its two fruits, namely the human effort and dominant fruits.
If it is uncontaminated, it takes the dharmas of different stages as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and disjunction fruits.
Because it does not fall into the realms, it does not block the homogeneous cause.
Having explained the various stages, we will now explain the three kinds of karma of learners, etc.
The verse states:
Learners have three each in the three, non-learners have one, three, and two,
Non-learners and neither-learners-nor-non-learners have two, two, and five fruits.
The treatise states:

The three kinds of karma of learners, non-learners, and neither-learners-nor-non-learners each take the three dharmas as their fruits in order. This means that learner karma takes learner dharmas as its three fruits, excluding the karmic maturation and disjunction fruits;
taking non-learner dharmas as its three fruits is also the same;
taking neither as its three fruits excludes the karmic maturation and homogeneous fruits.
The karma of the post-learner has one fruit, which is the dominant fruit, with respect to the dharmas of the learner.

It has three fruits, excluding the homogeneous and the disconnection fruits, with respect to the post-learner.ğŸ”½It has two fruits, which are the human effort and dominant fruits, with respect to the two, neither learner nor post-learner.
The karma of neither learner nor post-learner has two fruits, which are the human effort and dominant fruits, with respect to the dharmas of the learner.
It has two fruits with respect to the post-learner, and it has five fruits with respect to the two, neither learner nor post-learner.
Having explained the learner, etc., now we will explain the three types of karma to be eliminated by seeing, etc.
The verse states:
The karma to be eliminated by seeing, etc., each has three fruits in turn.
The first has three, four, and one fruit; the middle has two, four, and three fruits;
The last has one, two, and four fruits. They should be understood in sequence.
The treatise states:

The three types of karma, to be eliminated by seeing, to be eliminated by cultivation, and not to be eliminated, each have three dharmas as their fruits in turn. The first, the karma to be eliminated by seeing, has the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing as its three fruits, excluding the homogeneous and disconnection fruits.
It has four fruits excluding the disconnection fruit with respect to dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation.
It has one fruit, the dominant fruit, with respect to dharmas not to be eliminated.
Karma to be eliminated by cultivation has two fruits, the human effort fruit and the dominant fruit, with respect to dharmas to be eliminated by insight.
It has four fruits excluding the disconnection fruit with respect to dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation.
It has three fruits excluding the maturational fruit and the similar fruit with respect to dharmas not to be eliminated.
The last, karma not to be eliminated, has one fruit, the dominant fruit, with respect to dharmas to be eliminated by insight.
It has two fruits, the human effort fruit and the dominant fruit, with respect to dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation.
It has four fruits excluding the maturational fruit with respect to dharmas not to be eliminated.

Having discussed the various karmas, we should ask:

Karma that should be done is the opposite of this, the third is the opposite of both.
The treatise says:
Some say that defiled karma is called should not be done because it arises from improper attention.
Other masters say:

Bodily, verbal, and mental karma that violates norms should also not be done, that is, all that should be practiced in this way, should abide in this way, should speak in this way, should wear robes in this way, should eat in this way, etc. If not done in this way, it is called should not be done because it does not accord with worldly propriety;
Karma that is the opposite of this is called should be done.
Some say that good karma is called should be done because it arises from proper attention.
Other masters say:
Bodily, verbal, and mental karma that accords with norms is also called should be done. The third is the opposite of both. The two explanations differ according to what is appropriate.
Does one action only project one birth, or does it project many births?
Also, is one birth projected by only one action, or is it projected by many actions?
A verse says:
One action projects one birth, many actions can perfect it.
The treatise says:
Based on our school's tenets, we should say:
Only one action projects one birth. The phrase one birth here refers to one class affiliation, because only after obtaining class affiliation is one said to be born.
If so, why did the Venerable Aniruddha say:

I remember that once, in a single act of giving food to a supreme field of merit, I obtained the karmic reward of being reborn seven times in the Heaven of the Thirty-three and seven times among humans as a wheel-turning sage king, and in my final birth I was born into the great ÅšÄkya family with abundant wealth and much happiness.

They are born in a family of great wealth and honor due to one karma, and due to the wisdom of past lives, they create more karma that leads to blessings in other lives. In this way, they continue until their final life, when they are born in a wealthy and noble family and attain the ultimate fruit. This is said to show that it is due to the power of the initial [karma].
It is like a person who, starting with one gold coin, trades it and gets a thousand gold coins.
He exclaims:
Originally, it was because I had one gold coin that I obtained great wealth and happiness.
There is another explanation:

In the past, he relied on one act of giving food and gave rise to many superior thoughts and vows, some leading to the heavens and some leading to the human realm. The moments are not the same, and the ripening has a sequence of earlier and later. Therefore, one karma cannot lead to many lives, and one life is not led by many karmas.
Do not let the homogeneous groups be divided and distinguished.
Although it is only one karma that leads to one homogeneous group, it is allowed that its completion is due to many karmas.
It is like a painter who first sketches the form with one color and then fills in the many colors.

Therefore, although all people are born with a complete body, some are well endowed with limbs, organs, form, color, strength, and other characteristics, while others are deficient in these. Birth is not only due to the power of karma.
All unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas have retribution and are therefore able to attract and complete birth. Since karma is superior, it is given the name of karma.
However, those that exist together with karma are able to attract and complete birth, because they are superior to karma.
Those that do not exist together with karma are able to complete birth but not attract it, because their power is weak.
What are the natures of these two kinds of dharmas?

Commentary:
The so-called uninterrupted karmas are the five uninterrupted karmas.

First, frequently occurring, referring to constantly arising afflictions.
Second, intense, referring to strong afflictions.
One should know that here only the frequently occurring ones are called the hindrance of afflictions.

The numerous and active afflictions of eunuchs, etc., are difficult to subdue and eliminate, and therefore they are said to constitute an obstacle.ğŸ”½Even though the strong and intense afflictions are difficult to subdue and eliminate, they are not always active and therefore are not said to constitute an obstacle.

The numerous and active afflictions of the weak and medium categories are not strong and intense, but they are difficult to subdue and eliminate. They are difficult to subdue because they are always active and one has no opportunity to subdue them.

That is, they take the weak category as a condition to produce the medium category, and the medium category as a condition to produce the strong category, and the path that subdues and eliminates them has no opportunity to arise.
Therefore, among the afflictions, only those that are numerous and active, whether strong or weak, are called the obstacle of the afflictions.
The three evil destinies, the human destiny, Uttarakuru, and the heaven of non-percipient beings are called the obstacle of retribution.
What does this obstacle obstruct?
It obstructs the holy path and the wholesome roots that are the preparation for the holy path.

Also, in the obstacle of karma, one should also discuss the other definite karmas, that is, all the other karmas that definitely produce the evil destinies, birth from an egg, birth from moisture, the female body, the eighth existence, etc.
However, if there is an action that is easy to see and easy to know due to five causes, it is mentioned here, namely, place, realm, rebirth, fruit, and individual.
Among all actions, only the five uninterrupted [paths] have these five kinds, which are easy to see and easy to know. Other actions are not like this, so they are not mentioned here.
The other obstacles should be established as appropriate.

Discussion:
The uninterrupted karmas exist only in the three continents of humans, not in Uttarakuru or in other destinies or realms.
Among the three continents, only women and men commit the uninterrupted karmas, not eunuchs, etc.
